choices.C: Create a Feature Release alert in the Alert Center to be alerted to new functionality.
choices.A: Develop a cadence of regular roadmap and business reviews with your partner.
choices.B: Regularly scan the admin console and keep track of any new features you identify.
choices.D: Put half of your organization on the Rapid Release Schedule to highlight differences.

questions.question_text:
With the help of a partner, you deployed G Suite last year and have seen the rapid pace of innovation and development within the platform. Your CIO has requested that you develop a method of staying up-to-date on all things G Suite so that you can be prepared to take advantage of new features and ensure that your organization gets the most out of the platform.
What should you do?

discussion.content: A is the correct answer. (Even though it's not the best method)

Selected Answer: A
Option C doesn't exists. A is the closest to be accurate answer. Ref: https://support.google.com/a/answer/6131189?hl=en

Selected Answer: A
A is the only option wihtin the choice.
But it would be easier to subscribe to GW update newsletter.
No other best possible option than A.

G Suite Release Calendar
See details about new updates, releases, and training resources conveniently on your own calendar. You can also turn on notifications to get emails or SMS messages when release dates

questions.question_text:
The CFO just informed you that one of their team members wire-transferred money to the wrong account because they received an email that appeared to be from the CFO. The CFO has provided a list of all users that may be responsible for sending wire transfers. The CFO also provided a list of banks the company sends wire transfers to. There are no external users that should be requesting wire transfers. The CFO is working with the bank to resolve the issue and needs your help to ensure that this does not happen again.
What two actions should you take? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: B&D or B&E?? Confused as they are all quite close
B and E, because this is clear case of spoofing and phishing.
i vote B & D, this context no include external email and this question say "There are no external users that should be requesting wire transfers"

comments.content: How would you create a "rule requiring secure transport for all messages regarding wire transfers"? You could force TLS for the company domain but how would you do it for messages regarding wire transfers?

choices.E: Enable all admin settings in Gmail's safety > spoofing and authentication.
choices.C: Create a rule requiring secure transport for all messages regarding wire transfers.
choices.B: Verify that DMARC, DKIM, and SPF records are configured correctly for your domain.
choices.A: Configure objectionable content to reject messages with the words "wire transfer."
choices.D: Add the sender of the wire transfer email to the blocked senders list.

choices.A: Use Roles, Script, and Owner access permissions for operations on records and data relations.
choices.D: Change owner access permissions to allow internal usage only.
choices.C: Use a service account with limited permissions to access each data source.
choices.B: Enable App Maker access only for the Finance department Organization Unit.

discussion.content:
A is correct answer here, read below link for more details

https://developers.google.com/appmaker/security/overview

questions.question_text:
Your-company.com finance departments want to create an internal application that needs to read data from spreadsheets. As the collaboration engineer, you suggest using App Maker. The Finance team is concerned about data security when creating applications with App Maker.
What security measures should you implement to secure data?

choices.C: Use the Data Migration Service to transfer the data to a managed account.
choices.B: Use the Transfer Tool for unmanaged accounts to invite users into the domain.
choices.D: Open a support ticket to have Google transfer unmanaged accounts into your domain.
choices.A: Disable access to all "Other Services" in the G Suite Admin Console.

questions.question_text:
Your company is in the process of deploying Google Drive Enterprise for your sales organization. You have discovered that there are many unmanaged accounts across your domain. Your security team wants to manage these accounts moving forward.
What should you do?

choices.A: Review the authorized applications for each user via the G Suite Admin panel.
choices.C: Review the token audit log, and compile a list of all the applications and their scopes.
choices.D: Review the API permissions installed apps list, and export the list.
choices.B: Create a survey via Google forms, and collect the application data from users.

comments.content: agree with HateMicrosoft, the correct answer is D you get a list of all applications with the number of users who are using them

discussion.content:
D is correct.

If you go to Admin Console > Security > Access and data controls > API Controls > Manage Third Party App Access > You will see an option to "Download list"
it is C, beacuse the app list from Review the API permissions installed apps list can not be exported

comments.content: Actually it can. In Security > API Controls > App Access Control there's a button Download app info that exports a CSV

discussion.content: will swear by C, its correct answer.

questions.question_text:
Your chief compliance officer is concerned about API access to organization data across different cloud vendors. He has tasked you with compiling a list of applications that have API access to G Suite data, the data they have access to, and the number of users who are using the applications.
How should you compile the data being requested?
